action.action-desc: Mr. Begich introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation

form.official-title: To amend the statutory authorities of the Coast Guard to improve the quality of life for current and former Coast Guard personnel and their families, and for other purposes.

section.header: Short title; references to title 14, United States Code

subsection.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Coast Guard Quality of Life Act
.

subsection.header: References to title 14, United States Code
subsection.text: Except as otherwise expressly provided, whenever in this Act an amendment or repeal is expressed in terms of an amendment to, or repeal of, a section or other provision, the reference shall be considered to be made to a section or other provision of title 14, United States Code.

section.header: Expedited reimbursement for medical goods and services
section.text: Notwithstanding section 1085 of title 10, United States Code, or any other requirements under chapter 55 of that title providing for the reimbursement of inpatient or outpatient medical or dental care that the Department of Defense or a military department has provided to a member or former member of the Coast Guard or a dependent thereof, the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating, in lieu of such reimbursement, shall transfer from funds appropriated for the operating expenses of the Coast Guard an amount determined by the Board of Actuaries to represent the value of care that the Department of Defense or a military department shall provide, during the fiscal year in which funds are made available, to a member or former member of the Coast Guard or a dependent thereof.

section.header: Flag officers; determination of unfitness

subsection.text: Subchapter D of chapter 11 is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Flag officers; determination of unfitness
section.text: When the Coast Guard is not operating as a service in the Navy—

paragraph.text: section 1216(d) of title 10 shall not apply with respect to any member who is a flag officer being processed for retirement by reason of age or length of service; and
the Secretary may, with respect to any member who is a flag officer being processed for retirement by reason of age or length of service—

subparagraph.text: retire such member under section 1201 of title 10;
place such member on the temporary disability retired list under section 1202 of title 10; or
separate such member from the Coast Guard under section 1203 of title 10;

paragraph.continuation-text: by reason of unfitness to perform the duties of the flag officer’s office, grade, rank, or rating without approval by the Secretary of Defense or the recommendation of the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Health Affairs.

subsection.text: The table of contents for subchapter D of chapter 11 is amended by adding at the end, the following:

section.header: Coast Guard remission of indebtedness

subsection.text:
Section 461
is amended to read as follows:

section.header: Remission of indebtedness
section.text: The Secretary or the Secretary’s designee may have remitted or cancelled any part of a person's indebtedness to the United States or any instrumentality of the United States if—

paragraph.text: the indebtedness was incurred while the person served on active duty as a member of the Coast Guard; and
the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee considers remitting or cancelling any part of the indebtedness to be in the best interest of the United States.

section.header: Coast guard family support and child care

paragraph.text: Chapter 13 of part I is amended by redesignating section 514 as section 541.

subsection.text: Part I is amended by inserting before section 541, as redesignated, the following:

chapter.header: Coast Guard family support and child care authorities

section.header: Work-life policies and programs

paragraph.text: to establish a program for the purpose of developing and promulgating policies that promote or support the well-being of Coast Guard active duty, reserve, and civilian personnel, and their families;
to implement and oversee the policies under paragraph (1) as the Commandant considers necessary; and
to perform such other duties as the Commandant considers necessary to promote or support the well-being of Coast Guard active duty, reserve, and civilian personnel, and their families.

section.header: Surveys of Coast Guard families

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Commandant, in order to determine the effectiveness of Federal programs that promote or support the well-being of Coast Guard active duty, reserve, and civilian personnel, and their families, may survey—

paragraph.text: any Coast Guard active duty, reserve, or civilian personnel;
any retired Coast Guard member or civilian personnel;
the immediate family of any member or personnel described under paragraph (1) or paragraph (2); and
any survivor of a deceased member.

subsection.text: Participation in any survey conducted under this section shall be voluntary.

With respect to a survey authorized under subsection (a) that includes a person referred to in that subsection who is not an employee of the United States or is not otherwise considered an employee of the United States for the purposes of section 3502(3)(A)(i) of title 44, the person shall be considered an employee of the United States for the purposes of that section.
Part I is amended by inserting after section 541, as redesignated, the following:

section.header: Education and training opportunities for Coast Guard spouses

subsection.text: The Commandant may provide, subject to the availability of appropriations, tuition assistance to an eligible spouse of a member of the Coast Guard in achieving—

paragraph.text: the education and training required for a degree or credential, that expands employment and portable career opportunities for the spouse, at an accredited college, university, or technical school in the United States; or

the education prerequisites and professional licensure or credentialing required by a government or government-sanctioned licensing body for an occupation that expands employment and portable career opportunities for the spouse.

subsection.text: For the purposes of this section—

subparagraph.text: The term eligible spouse means the spouse of a member of the Coast Guard who is serving on active duty, including a spouse who receives transitional support in the case of such a member who is discharged due to domestic violence.
The term eligible spouse does not include—

clause.text: a person who is married to, but legally separated from, a member of the Coast Guard under court order or statute of any State or territorial possession of the United States; or
a person who is eligible for tuition assistance as a member of the armed forces.

paragraph.text: The term portable career opportunities includes an occupation requiring education, training, or both, that results in a credential that is recognized by an industry, profession, or specific type of business.

section.header: Youth sponsorship initiatives

subsection.text: The Commandant is authorized to establish, within any Coast Guard unit, an initiative to help integrate into new communities the dependent children of members of the Coast Guard when the members receive permanent change of station orders.
A youth sponsorship initiative under this section shall—

paragraph.text: apply to a dependent child who resides in the new community due to a permanent change of station order;
provide for the involvement of a dependent child of a member of the Coast Guard in the dependent child's new Coast Guard community; and
primarily focus on children in their preteen and teenage years.
Part I is amended by inserting before section 552, as redesignated, the following:

section.header: Definitions

paragraph.text:
The term child abuse and neglect has the meaning given the term in section 3 of the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act (
42 U.S.C. 5101 note).

The term child development center employee means a civilian employee of the Coast Guard who is employed to work in a Coast Guard child development center regardless of whether the employee is paid from appropriated or nonappropriated funds.

subparagraph.text: The term Coast Guard child development center means a facility on Coast Guard property or on property under the jurisdiction of the commander of a Coast Guard unit, at which child care services are provided for members of the Coast Guard.
The term Coast Guard child development center does not include a child care services facility for which space is allotted under section 590 of title 40.

paragraph.text: The term competitive service position means a position in the competitive service (as defined in section 2102(a)(1) of title 5).
The term family home daycare means home-based child care services provided for a member of the Coast Guard by an individual who—

subparagraph.text: is certified by the Commandant as qualified to provide home-based child care services; and
provides home-based child care services on a regular basis in exchange for monetary compensation.

It is the sense of the Congress that the amount of appropriated funds available during a fiscal year for operating expenses for Coast Guard child development services should be, at a minimum, not less than the amount of child development center fee receipts that are estimated to be collected by the Coast Guard during that fiscal year. In this subparagraph, the term child development center fee receipts means those nonappropriated funds derived from fees paid by members of the Coast Guard for child care services provided at Coast Guard child development centers.
Section 552 , as redesignated, is amended—

clause.text: in subsection (b)(2)(B), by inserting Waiver authority.— before Fees to be charged; and
in subsection (b)(2)(C), by inserting Fee collection and use.— before The Commandant .

paragraph.header: Child development center standards and inspections
paragraph.text: Part I is amended—

subparagraph.text: in section 552, as redesignated—

clause.text: by redesignating subsection (d) as subsection (c); and

subparagraph.text: by adding after section 552, as redesignated, the following:

section.header: Child development center standards and inspections

subsection.text: The Commandant shall require that each child development center meets applicable health and safety standards.

The Commandant shall require that each child development center under this subchapter meets such safety standards as the Commandant considers appropriate to ensure the health, safety, and welfare of the children and employees at the child development center.
The Commandant shall provide for regular and unannounced inspections of each child development center under this subchapter to ensure compliance with this section.

paragraph.text: The Commandant shall maintain and publicize a means by which an individual can report—

subparagraph.text: any suspected violation of—
any suspected child abuse or neglect; or
any other deficiency at a Coast Guard child development center or in family home daycare.

paragraph.text: The Commandant shall ensure that a report under paragraph (1) can be made anonymously if so desired by the individual making the report.
The Commandant shall establish procedures for investigating a report under paragraph (1).
Part I is amended by adding after section 553 the following:

section.header: Child development center employees

paragraph.text: The Commandant shall prescribe a training program for Coast Guard child development center employees. Satisfactory completion of the training program shall be a condition of employment for an employee of a Coast Guard child development center. The Commandant shall require each employee complete the training program not later than 6 months after the date that the employee is employed as a Coast Guard child development center employee.
The training program shall include, at a minimum, instruction in the following:

subparagraph.text: Early childhood development.
Activities and disciplinary techniques appropriate to children of different ages.
Child abuse and neglect prevention and detection.
Cardiopulmonary resuscitation and other emergency medical procedures.

paragraph.header: Use of department of defense programs
paragraph.text: The Commandant may use Department of Defense training programs on a reimbursable or nonreimbursable basis, for purposes of complying with the requirements of this subsection.
The Commandant shall require that at least 1 employee at each Coast Guard child development center be a specialist in training and curriculum development with appropriate credentials and experience.
The duties of the employee under paragraph (1) shall include the following:

subparagraph.text: Special teaching activities at the Coast Guard child development center.
Daily oversight and instruction of other child care employees at the Coast Guard child development center.
Daily assistance in the preparation of lesson plans.
Assisting with child abuse and neglect prevention and detection at the Coast Guard child development center.
Advising the director of the Coast Guard child development center on the performance of the other child care employees.

paragraph.text: Each employee under paragraph (1) shall be an employee in a competitive service position.

section.header: Parent partnerships with child development centers

paragraph.text: The Commandant shall require that there be formed at each Coast Guard child development center a board of parents, to be composed of parents of children attending the center.
Each parent board shall—

subparagraph.text: meet periodically with the staff and the commander of the unit served by the center at which the parent board is formed, for the purpose of discussing problems and concerns; and
be responsible, together with the staff of that center, for coordinating the parent participation initiative required under subsection (b).

paragraph.text: A board of parents under this subsection shall not be subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act (5 U.S.C. App.).

The Commandant is authorized to establish a parent participation initiative at each Coast Guard child development center to encourage and facilitate parent participation in educational and related activities at the center.
The Commandant, in the case of a parent who participates in an initiative adopted under paragraph (1), may establish fees at a lower rate than charged under section 552(b)(2)(A) for that parent.

section.header: Officer evaluation reports

subsection.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Commandant of the Coast Guard shall provide the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate and the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure of the House of Representatives a written assessment of the Coast Guard’s current officer evaluation reporting system.
The assessment required under subsection (a) shall include, at a minimum, an analysis of—

paragraph.text: the extent to which the Coast Guard’s current officer evaluation reports differ in length, form, and content from the officer fitness reports used by the Navy and other branches of the armed forces;
the extent to which such differences are the result of inherent differences in the Coast Guard and the Navy, and in the Coast Guard and other branches of the armed forces;
the feasibility of better aligning and conforming the Coast Guard’s officer evaluation reports with the officer fitness reports of the Navy and other branches of the armed forces; and

the costs and benefits of such improved alignment and conformity, including with respect to Coast Guard administrative efficiency and the Coast Guard’s statutory mission of defense readiness, including when operating as a service in the Navy.

section.header: Housing choices for Coast Guard families with special medical needs

subsection.text: The remoteness or driving distance from a hospital of an area shall not be the basis, in policy, for preventing a member of the Coast Guard with a dependent with special medical needs, such as diabetes, asthma, or moderate disabilities, from residing in a particular area, unless the Commandant has determined that such needs cannot be sufficiently met with appropriate services while residing in that area.

section.header: Post-service maritime employment opportunities

subsection.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Commandant shall take steps to promote better awareness, on an ongoing basis, among Coast Guard personnel regarding post-service use of Coast Guard training, education, and practical experience as qualifying experience in satisfaction of requirements for merchant mariner credentials under section 11.213 of title 46, Code of Federal Regulations.

section.header: Timely provision of sea service letters

subsection.text: A member of the Coast Guard who retires or separates from the Service and who is eligible to receive a sea service letter shall be provided such sea service letter, at the member's request, on or before the member's retirement or separation date.
